Malone in Talks to Increase Stake in News Corporation John C. Malone and Rupert Murdoch are considering a deal that would increase the size of their investments in each other's companies, according to people close to the talks.

Under the complex transaction, Mr. Malone is considering putting his 20 percent stake of Gemstar-TV Guide International, along with some cable holdings in Latin America, into Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation. In exchange, Mr. Malone's Liberty Media, which already owns 8 percent of News Corporation, would increase its stake in the company to 20 percent and would receive stock in News Corporation's global satellite TV operations. [Page C2.]

Holes Seen in Investor Safety Net At a time when millions of people have taken their money out of banks and put it into brokerage firms, the Securities Investor Protection Corporation's responsibility for protecting the investing public has never been more important. But a close look at the organization shows that the safety net that investors think the corporation offers is in fact full of holes. [A1.]

Staking a Claim in Latin America Operators of e-marketplaces -- Internet portals through which companies do business with one another -- are betting on the democratizing power of the Internet to break down the barriers that confine most small companies in Latin America to doing business within 30 miles of home. E-marketplaces are still struggling to work out the kinks, but the obstacles are not deterring Internet companies from racing to stake a claim in the market for business-to-business e-commerce in Latin America. New Economy. [C4.]

BP Amoco in Talks on Joint Venture BP Amoco is in talks to form a joint venture with the oil and gas arm of RWE, the German utility. Separately, RWE is expected to announce today that it has agreed to buy Thames Water for $6.25 billion. [C2.]

Lucent and MapInfo Develop Service Responding to a growing sector of the wireless Internet industry, Lucent Technologies and MapInfo are expected to announce today that they will jointly develop location-based services for mobile communications devices. [C6.]

Joint Effort by Motorola and Palm Motorola and Palm plan to announce today that they will collaborate on a new portable phone that would put the features of a Palm hand-held computer into a device closer to the size and shape of a cell phone. [C6.]

The Middlemen of Online Content Generating content for Web sites has proved much harder than many Internet companies had expected. The problem has not been lost on so-called online content syndicators, which act as intermediaries between sites that need content and sites that want to sell it. Meanwhile, media companies and others that supply content have found that syndicators have given them a much-needed revenue source. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C12.]

China Allows Photo Book to Leave Last week, Chinese officials reversed course and agreed to allow a book by a former White House photographer out of the country. Chinese officials had stopped 17,000 copies of the book at its bindery last month because it contained a picture of President Clinton chatting with the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism and an icon of Tibet's cultural autonomy from China. [C17.]

Online Travel Agency Is Postponed Orbitz, an online travel agency being started by five major airlines, has postponed its rollout until next June. Still, it has already signed up more than 50,000 potential customers. [C4.]
Seagram Managers Won't Make Bid A consortium led by managers of Seagram's spirits and wine unit has decided not to bid for the business, which is up for sale. [C19.]
